author: Buttercup7654
title: Staff do an amazing job
body:
Son triaged by 111 and got a call OOH doc who made an appt to be seen.  
Seen, given meds and reassurance and back home within an hour.  
Staff were friendly and from 111 to OOH were quick and efficient and listened to me and my concerns. A very busy service, staff do an amazing job.

author: Mags55
title: Superb, informative and reassuring
body:
Attended recently for trans nasal endoscopy.  
Arrived for appointment after 08:00 and left by 09:30. If NHS Lothian's vision for the future is outpatient care and treatment being the norm, this is a perfect example. You arrive for a procedure and leave with informal results handed to you while waiting formal results from the labs. An uncomfortable procedure as you would expect but so much better than previous experience involving an almost all day procedure with sedation. Staff were superb, informative and reassuring from start to end. A real and genuine team. Thanks to all.

author: Gavhino
title: Condition Management Programme
body:
General physical ailments, primarily lower back pain.  
Back injury from ten plus years earlier, general wear and tear from years of manual labour.  
Other issues include a fairly long standing shoulder injury. Difficulty in completing manual labour for any length of time.  
Periods spent standing or walking became unmanageable especially in previous working environments.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Millie22
title: No one called back
body:
I called NHS24 due to my c-section scar appearing to be infected. It has two open sections and very hard sizeable lump. ? Abscess. I also had a temperature of 38. I have recently had IV abx and an oral course after the section so this was concerning me. I was then referred to OOH for a call back. This never happened.  
I called NHS 24 back again in the early hours of the morning after waiting over an hour to get through. They said my record had gone down to the out of hours and they must just be busy and to wait or contact my gp. No body phoned me back. That’s over 12 hours.  
I really find this unacceptable.

author: Ozzy23
title: My brother's cancer care
body:
I am so angry and annoyed by the trust right from the GP in Enniskillen to the specialists in Altnagelvin hospital in Derry. My brother has really suffered at their hands from being diagnosed with cancer which I felt could have been avoided if the GP hadn’t of kept sending him away.  
The cancer he was diagnosed with is curable if caught in time. He was given the all clear and then 2 weeks later he was given only months to live - there is something badly wrong here. He suffered with the same pain in his head and eye from the first time he came out of Altnagelvin hospital. From his first treatment during covid the pain was mention at every appointment he has been to, and that’s a hell of a lot.  
He was admitted into Omagh hospital and primary care palliative care ward. This was supposed to be for two weeks. He ended up spending twelve weeks there on a syringe driver and was discharged still with the same pain. On numerous occasions we had to bring him to the GP and also ring them and the pain was mentioned at every single appointment he attended in Altnagelvin.  
They did a CT scan from the neck down even though he was suffering from pain in his head and eye. I asked why they didn’t scan his head and the doctor in Altnagelvin informed us that it doesn’t normally travel upwards.  
We feel as a family we have been badly let down and mistreated from the very beginning and now my younger brother has only got a short time left. We as a family are furious as we feel this could have been different. We are disgusted at how he has been treated and we do not want this to happen to another person or their family. It is devastating and heartbreaking to watch knowing that you only have a very short time left with him - all this could have been avoided we feel.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

author: Wee Max
title: The physio care I received.
body:
I fractured my femur and was operated on 10 weeks ago.  
I was appointed two physio’s from Hunter’s health East Kilbride.  
These two ladies were my strength, namely Lauren and Rachel.  
Rachel, is a student who was very caring and attentive. From day one I felt comfortable and their methods worked a treat.  
In my opinion Rachel would be an asset to any team.  
Thank you

author: Smee So'tis
title: Covid nMabs
body: In for my covid neutralising monoclonal antibody (nMAb) at Dundonald hospital . Unsure what to expect but was put at ease by the excellent care and service of nurses Jenny and Lisa and Dr.Victoria .

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: PumpkinPie
title: Autism awareness - A&E
body:
The service was alright but my main issue was the way that Doctors treat those with invisible disabilities such as autism.  
I felt one doctor was unbelievably rude and callous when I explained I was autistic. I felt they dismissed my disability like it wasn't real.  
I'm disappointed because this doctor would have had a decade or more medical training, and I feel, should be highly educated and highly dependable. But they were rude, unfriendly, dismissive and disbelieving.  
Perhaps your doctors need some further training so they know that you don't have to look autistic to be autistic.

author: victorhj59
title: Stroke rehab team
body:
When my wife came out of hospital after her stroke the team appeared really quickly.  
The initial assessments by Leanne, Helen, and Roanne to provide in quick succession walking frame, seat, and other aids was impressive and quite reassuring. Initially, speech and therapy sessions were the hardest for my wife, but Margaret was so calm, and clear in explaining everything. We can now have a good conversation and know what to do when things are tricky.  
After almost 2 months in hospital the physio, and approach was entirely different, it was all geared to the future and getting her ready for daily life. Looking back her progress has been significant. I remember that it was me who initially noticed a movement in one of her fingers in the ward after 40 days – that sparked quite a bit of physio activity. The changes at home have been daily, weekly and ongoing.  
We have had a pattern of an average of 3 physio sessions a week, largely due to Tracey coming twice a week when she is available. Often the lead physio Helen, is supported by Emma or Leanne. We have always been able to talk progress through with any of the team, that has been a feature of each visit we tend to have chat before the serious work starts, and often at the end, to clarify any points. All the members of the team are so easy to talk to and patient, when explaining to me in particular why I should be doing something.  
I do not see how she could have had a better service, especially throughout this covid period. Helen went out of her way to come to our second Orthotics appointment, and was on hand when my wife decided she needed the toilet whilst they made adjustments to her splint. It went well and I believe that gave her confidence for the future use of disabled toilets. Helen offered to involve the carers in various elements of my wife's progress unfortunately for various reasons not always practical.  
Now that we have the blue badge, and ramps we are mobile daily, and with the garage modifications and the rear ramps my wife can use the back garden. So a lot of thanks to Roanne.  
I would recommend your team to anyone who needs you, you are all brilliant.

readBy.name: Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

author: pictorjc64
title: Appointment Letter
body:
I received a letter dated the 5th to let me know about an appointment on the 4th. Pretty sure I can't go back in time, nor can your staff so not sure why they thought it was a useful exercise.  
I would appreciate it if you could tell the Haematology department that I didn't ignore their phone call but instead let them know of the incompetency of the letter drop and arrange another appointment for myself.

author: Garden Mum
title: My Gynae examination appointment.
body:
I didn't actually see the Doctor who had promised to see me during my phone appointment. They had said that should they not be able to see me they would reschedule the appointment.  
This didn't happen, I was very disappointed especially as the examination was very uncomfortable.  
It also left me very uncomfortable and passing blood spots for several days, I am not due any follow-up or further appointment with anyone.  
NB I'm an elderly lady. Yet again, despite their reassurances during my phone appointment; the appointment I received was unsatisfactory, the whole reason they promised to be at my appointment.

author: N.mora
title: Stroke rehabilitation
body:
One weekend in early June I realised there was something wrong with my right arm. I then called my GP on the Monday morning and was referred to a clinic at the Victoria Hospital.  
I had a brain scan at the clinic, which had shown that I had a stroke two years previous. I had not noticed this. I was then admitted to ward 42 at the Victoria.  
The treatment at ward 42 was very good. I was made feel welcome, I couldn’t fault them. I received 3 MRI scans whilst in the VHK. Physiotherapy was very difficult at first. I was then transferred to Letham Ward Cameron Hospital for further Rehabilitation.  
Whilst at Cameron there was nodules found on my spine, all communications to the Western General was dealt with quickly. Physiotherapy very challenging.  
I became frustrated and angry at the beginning, now I understand why Physiotherapy did what they did. Activities helped me a lot , I enjoyed working on the jigsaws and the hand physio box that the Activities coordinator made for me. Also I enjoyed sudoku and crosswords for activities.  
The first bed was a little high for me, this was corrected very quickly . Meal choices became very repetitive after being here for many months.  
I cannot fault the staff at Letham ward, whatever I needed I got. I have had a lot of trouble with the diabetic team at the VHK, it has has taken months for my monitor etc to be sorted.  
I am where I am today with my Rehab because of the Staff at Letham Ward.

author: Heaye79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Comfortable and listened to
body:
My Heart Failure nurse Barbara comes to visit me at home.  
I never feel rushed, she listens to me and makes me feel comfortable.  
Barbara is amazing, thank you!

author: Heaye79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Pleasant team
body:
My husband is seen by the heart failure nurses in their clinic. The nurses always keep to the allotted appointment times so we have never had to wait.  
Overall a very pleasant team.

author: rainhr34
title: My mother was diagnosed with cancer
body:
My mother was diagnosed with terminal cancer in March 2022. She wanted to die at home.  
The only reason she could was the service provided by the home care staff by South Ayrshire Council.  
The care my mother received was of the highest standard; the staff arrived at 7 o'clock every morning to give her a wash and to make her a breakfast. They were a godsend as our family is small, so it was only my brother and me. The staff were always kind, friendly and reliable. My mum died at home peacefully and I will be always grateful to the care at home staff of SAC. Thank you.

readBy.name: South Ayrshire Health and Social Care Partnership
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Staff so efficient
body:
I can’t complain a single bit about the care that I have been receiving. Honestly it’s been brilliant, so far the staff real have been faultless.  
The nurses in the hospital are incredibly kind answering my requests very efficiently and are extremely passionate you can tell how much they enjoy their job and they put it before everything with their priority being the patients.  
The doctors are the same well and truly great explain everything and can understand most of what they say.  
I have had no issues whatsoever with any of the care that I have seen

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The care that I have gotten so far has really been brilliant
body: The care that I have gotten in the hospital so far has really been brilliant, and I am very happy with the facet they have given me, zero issues. Ever since I was admitted the staff up the ward have been incredibly nice. The nurses are absolutely great, day or night, no matter what I ask of them, they help me get, even if it’s a question they do their best to answer. The doctors are great and have been able to explain a lot about the treatment and care that I have gotten. I have been in 4 weeks and hope I get some positive tests so I can get discharge.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Staff second to none
body: The staff in the hospital have been second to none so far and there honestly isn’t a bad word I could say about them. The nurses are always so kind and no matter what I ask of them they always do their best to help. The doctors are the same, explaining everything in a way I understand. The food and leaning have also been pretty decent, no real complaints I could make about anything. The care has been well and truly great and I am so happy that I’ve have had no issues so far.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Doctors are round every morning
body: The care that I have gotten in the hospital, it has been absolutely brilliant so far and I have had absolutely no issues with any of the care that I have been receiving. The nurses have all been very good so far which I am very thankful for as the care I have got from them is second to none. The nurses are some of the best about and no matter what I ask of them are willing to help me out. The doctors are great round every morning giving me updates on everything and explaining it. There have been no problems with my care and I am happy with everything I’ve seen, especially with the staff.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Matdw53
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Happy enough with everything
body: The care in Orthopaedics Ward has been so brilliant so far and there are definitely no issues on my end. The nurses that the hospital has have been pretty good and I know that no matter what I they need will offer to help. The doctors are also great and have been so easy to understand while answering all my questions that I have. The food has been pretty decent can’t really complain about it. There isn’t a bad word I could say about the care I am happy enough with everything.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Echoing Green
title: I feel very grateful for the care
body: So much is said about delays and difficulties in A&E there days that I just want to record the kindness and efficiency of my visit. I was lucky that it wasn't a busier time. The wait was 2 hours, as advertised at Reception, and once my turn came, the process progressed steadily. What made it a supportive experience was the personal and gently humorous way the team looked after me during the x-raying and bone-aligning processes - the latter being done very successfully (and with excellent analgesic). I feel very grateful for the care of this kindly and expert team.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: JazzyS
title: Issues getting in contact
body:
Left a text for my first appointment with a number to call if I could not make the date and time. I couldn't make the day so I called and got through to a staff member who asked which doctor my appointment was with, and put me through to that doctor's receptionist. The phone rang and then stopped.  
It has been difficult enough for me to get help, then get CBT that only made things worse. I am extremely anxious taking this step and having no one at the end of the phone does not help.

author: Heaye79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: They have given me back my confidence
body:
The heart failure nurses really do care. The nurses listen to me, keep me up to date with any information I need. They also liaise with my GP.  
They genuinely seem interested in me.  
I was told I can call them if I was worried about anything, which was kind.  
I had lost my confidence, but thanks to them I have got my confidence back.

author: septemberpg96
title: Needs an update
body:
I am a wheelchair user, unable to walk and staying at the center. When i mentioned the issues around accessibility I was asked to call and told that I could give feedback through Care Opinion. So, the majority of the equipment is old and not suitable:  
Mirrors - positioned too high cannot see through them.  
Sinks - again positioned in a way that makes them very very difficult to use, sort of have to use them at a slant.  
Soap dispensers - too high, difficult to use.  
Paper towels - again too high, cannot reach them  
Grab rails - wrong position to grab, cannot hold them to adjust shower head height, cannot adjust temperature.  
Water - either too hot or too cold  
Lights - cannot access the light switch to turn on/off lights  
Doors - too heavy to open/close  
Garden - again door too heavy to use - need to ask staff or family to help  
I feel that the whole center needs an upgrade, modernisation and a rethink about accessibility.  
The care is all fine and the staff are all nice.  
We have a weekly meeting and these will be discussed but I've been told that the more feedback we give the more chance there is of change, so I am giving my feedback.

readBy.name: Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust

author: ER30
title: Care received at the Ulster Hospital
body:
I contracted Covid, and because I am on immune suppressing drugs, my GP passed my details on to see if I could receive the neutralising antibody infusion.  
A doctor named Victoria called me yesterday, to see if I would like to go to the Ulster Hospital this morning for the infusion. She was very nice and explained why it would be recommended, so I said I would definitely like to have it.  
I arrived at the hospital this morning and was met by two nurses, Jenny and Lisa. The doctor Victoria also came along to introduce herself.  
The nurses were so friendly and attentive and explained everything. I just felt so at ease. There was another patient in and we were all talking and having a bit of fun, so the time passed quickly. Jenny went to make tea and coffee. When I told her I only drink decaf, she said she had decaf coffee. I couldn’t believe it. The first time I have been able to get decaf in a hospital! It was lovely and we also received a snack pack with water, crisps, yogurt, biscuits etc.  
The only reason I wouldn’t want to go back there again is because it would mean I had Covid again!!!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jendy9
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: If it goes we may never get it back
body:
The patient wrote to our Chief Executive to say thank you for the care he had received at Lincoln County Hospital. He said he witnessed dedicated nurses and doctors, he saw the power of healing and wanted to thank everyone in the NHS and especially the nurse who held his hand during his endoscopy.  
The patient wanted his thanks to be shared but said, (in his own words) that he had a little learning about a lot of things but knows nothing about the internet and asked us to share the following on Care Opinion:  
_________________  
The performances of the NHS Trusts, hospitals and staff generally cannot be faulted even though they seem to be hammered by politicians and their policies. A little while ago we were asked to clap for the NHS, now I strongly advise the nation to pray for the NHS to stop it being taken from us by unscrupulous politicians. If it goes we may never get it back.

author: al88
title: Ulster Hospital Maternity Unit
body:
I attended the Ulster Hospital maternity unit for my 20-week anomaly scan today.  
The sonographer was absolutely fantastic, they put myself and my partner at ease, explained everything they checked for, and was extremely patient when our baby was in an awkward position for a final check! The sonographer is a credit to the Trust and deserves recognition for their positive attitude.  
I only established the midwife's name from their name badge. I was disappointed that they didn’t introduce theirself, particularly as I know HSC has recently promoted the "Hello My Name Is” campaign.  
I was also disappointed to find the midwife left the door open during the consultation. Whilst they were pleasant enough, it felt rushed. As a first time mum to be, a little rapport building and privacy would have been appreciated.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: saturnsz68
title: Absolutely fabulous service
body: Rang to make an appointment, was called back by a junior doctor, discussed everything, arranged an appointment with the junior doctor. Clinic ran on time, doctor was fantastic, open, honest, concerned and listened to me. Examined me with another colleague in room as we are opposite sexes. Got another doctor in room for second opinion. All were superb and such a credit to their profession and the NHS. Absolutely fabulous service. Tested for everything as standard too. The female junior doctor who dealt with me has a great future in healthcare.

author: Heaye79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Very looked after
body:
The heart failure nurse is very nice, she answers all of my questions.  
I feel very looked after.

author: NHS Opinion
title: Should be a better triage system
body: Waited 8 hours in a second waiting room with nobody checking on anyone. Was then put in a room where in 12 hours I was seen once, as they had forgotten as wasn't an actual bed bay. Staff are absolutely run off their feet but should be a better triage system like during covid, as there were unnecessary patients who were not either an accident nor emergency.

author: orionnw67
title: We will forever remember their love and care
body:
Our little boy was born at 29 weeks and needed to stay in the neonatal unit at Craigavon for 6 weeks.  
Going for the first time to see our little boy in the neonatal unit was very scary for myself and my husband, but the staff were so supportive and caring to us and cared so much for our little boy, it made it slightly easier.  
Staff ensured that they kept us informed at all points in our little boy's care and allowed us when possible to get involved in his care. Nothing was too much for the staff, and when we had any questions they took the time to answer our question and ensure that we understood.  
The staff were so friendly and ensured that we were happy with the care that our little boy was receiving. The staff could not have done more for us as a family and we will forever remember their love and care for all the babies within the unit and all that they have done for us.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Heaye79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Met my expectations
body:
I feel the Heart Failure Service has met my expectations and the nurse seems to have everything under control.  
The nurses provide a valuable link between the hospital, myself and my GP.  
I feel supported by the service.

author: whispersw79
title: Processing what happened when I was younger
body: As a child I faced multiple forms of abuse which had a massive impact on my inner beliefs, though processes and relationships as an adult. After recently being in a very abusive relationship, I realised I needed help so with the help of my GP, I self referred to Inclusion Thurrock. I went under Intense CBT for just over six month to help with processing thoughts and processing what happened when I was younger. I’ve come out very confident and I’m excited for the future and learning what I’ve learnt moving forward

author: whitel02
title: Paediatric Bladder and Bowel Service
body:
Accessed help for my 7 year old with nocturnal enuresis (night time wetting) and was incredibly well-supported.  
We used the bedwetting alarm, and he gradually went longer and longer overnight being dry and within a few weeks was completely dry and has remained so since for several months now! He is delighted (as of course are we) and it has had a huge impact on our washing pile and his confidence.The members of the team we dealt with (sorry for forgetting names) were kind, patient and encouraging throughout and we really appreciated that when we didn't know what to try next.Keep up the great work and thank you again!

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: GrAndyP
title: Nothing was too much trouble
body:
Hearing check-up, as it'd worsened. Seen by the superb Helen, who was patience itself, holistic and advisory in approach before actually running tests. She responded to questions and set me up with an improved hearing aid and left me feeling that it mattered to her that she'd set me up properly.  
Nothing was too much trouble, just excellent.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: Maggiem
title: Thank you very much for your professionalism and care
body: Very stressed and worried about all the unpredictable changes with my dad. The Rapid Response Team came out, and they were brilliant, reassured us all, got him into bed with a hoist (not yet used due to OT delay), and most importantly communicated with us all in a really positive manner. We were so grateful, thank you very much for your professionalism and care.

author: Radquack
title: I was extremely impressed
body:
I was seen on time by Dr Divekar, who was most pleasant and professional. I was advised that I needed a lesion on my back excised, and referred on to a nurse specialist, Clarinda, and her assistant, Charlotte.  
The lesion was expertly and painlessly excised.  
I was extremely impressed by the standard of care I received from all dermatology staff.

author: Heaye79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: A great service
body:
The nurses from the Heart Failure team took time to listen to what I had to say, I find them very supportive and informative.  
I have monthly reviews which I find reassuring.  
Overall a great service!

author: Gary D
title: Wonderful people doing a wonderful job
body:
I was working alone in a community hall in a rural area of Islandmagee, Co.Antrim. I was constructing wooden storage cupboards which involved power tools. Unexpectedly a circular saw I was using kicked back out of a piece of timber and landed on my left arm between my thumb and index finger before running up my wrist approximately six inches. I immediately knew I had a serious injury. Using my right hand I immediately grasped the wound in order to stem blood loss. I ran outside to my work van, where my phone was. Fortunately the 'Emergency Call Only' icon appeared on the phone screen as I struggled to call for assistance. The Operator who received my call was great. She established my identity, location and extent of my injury and continued to reassure me. She quickly identified that the air ambulance would be the best first response. The operator remained on the line as other agencies were tasked and continued to reassure me and seek information. I do not know this lady's name but I would like to thank her for all she did. I was able to tell her when I could hear the helicopter. As the helicopter landed I could hear other sirens approach. I felt so relieved to hear these sounds. The Air Ambulance crew, paramedics and police officers all seemed to arrive within a short period of time. A police officer positioned himself to my side as I was assisted to the ground. I remember him applying pressure to the inside of my upper arm in order to restrict blood loss. I am very grateful to this officer who acted quickly. The Air Ambulance consultant (I think his name was Darren) immediately reassured me. He was the consummate professional. Calm, decisive, knowledgeable. He directed paramedic staff to apply a loose tourniquet and to remove my hand from my wound and apply bandage. I was removed to the paramedics' ambulance where the Consultant directed I be put on a drip and given morphine. He then instructed the ambulance crew to take me to The Ulster Hospital for the attention of the Plastics Dept. I would like to thank the Air Ambulance crew for both their rapid response and the expert medical treatment.  
The paramedic staff (Sharon and David I believe) who transported me to the Ulster Hospital were great. Sharon monitored my condition continually and reassured me. She was so kind. I would like to thank both these staff for their assistance.  
On arrival at the Ulster Hospital I received prompt attention. I was seen by numerous doctors and nurses all of who were wonderful. After assessment I was told I needed an operation which would probably be done the next day. I was consulted about whether I wanted to stay overnight in hospital or return home. I chose the latter. My wound was temporarily stitched and dressed before discharge.  
The following morning I returned to the Plastics Dept in the Ulster Hospital. I was admitted. I was allocated a room. This was amazing. My room was like a hotel with en suite toilet facilities, TV and remotely controlled lights and blinds. Incredible. In the evening I was taken to theatre. The staff where amazing. The reassured me and we joked light-heartedly. I felt safe in their hands. At midnight I awoke. I felt no pain. I felt very happy with everything. The following day the Consultant surgeon visited me with his entourage. He told me he had reconnected tendons, arteries and nerves and that all was well. I believe his name was Andrew. I would like to thank Andrew for his assistance and his excellent stitching. I can tell he tried to make good the mess I had made of my tattoos. The scarring will be minimal. The nursing staff on the ward were I recovered from the operation were so nice. I would like to thank them all. I would also like to thank the man who brought my food to me. He was courteous and friendly. A special mention to the male cleaner who sorted my room. He was a middle aged man and he made me laugh. I really liked him. Thank you Sir.  
After discharge from the ward I have attended the Hand clinic on several occasions. Once again I would like to thank the staff. I was seen by Tom on the first two occasions. Great at his job and super friendly. Janey, the consultant hand specialist, was so knowledgeable and gave me great insight into the nature of my injury and the rationale behind the physio programme. Janet was also brilliant. She gave me a detailed physio programme and also the confidence to follow it.  
My treatment is ongoing but I would like to put on record that I believe the treatment and care I have received from first point of contact with the telephone operator to date as not only been first class, but world class. I cannot think of a single area where I could suggest improvement. Wonderful people doing a wonderful job. Thank you all.  
PS. I have now set up a small monthly Standing Order to help fund the Air Ambulance.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: coinmn55
title: The ACT group
body: Love Becky's ACT group, great to be with people that understand so much.

author: juniper333
title: My CAMHS experience
body:
I initially got refereed to CAMHS when I was 12 for what was thought to be just anxiety and depression as diagnosed by the doctor.  
I was on the waiting list for 2 years, tried multiple ineffective therapists outwith the NHS, and my condition got a lot worse with the anxious and depressive symptoms. I initially got contacted by them in mid 2019 and turned it down because they didn't seem like they cared because of the long wait and no contact so how were they going to help?My mental health got a lot worse later in 2020 so the doctor referred me back to CAMHS again and we got an initial appointment to discuss what's going on followed by a few others with different doctors to discuss the same thing. It was sickeningly repetitive and felt like a dead end. My mental health continued to significantly worsen as 2021 rolled by with suicidal thoughts creeping in. I had another few repetitive appointments then I got booked in with online therapy as part of CAMHS. I found that it was quite useless, patronizing, being treated like a small child and again the same repetitive one size fits all thing I've seen within CAMHS.I then inquired about testing for autism as I felt I fit the criteria after my own research. I also inquired about medication for depression. This was about mid 2021. They put me on the autism test waiting list and medicine review waiting list, by this point I was pretty used to what felt like endless months of waiting between appointments.Near the end of 2021 was when I hit a crisis point and was suicidal. It felt like nobody could help me. We then got booked in with CAMHS again after my doctor insisted I have an appointment.It felt like in order for me to get any help from CAMHS I had to hit a point of being suicidal. I thought I was going in for a medication review and had a tiny spark of hope that something might help that was quickly crushed when I found out it was a risk assessment and I had to tell this new person the same thing I had told what felt like hundreds of doctors. I was frustrated with the lack of clarity about the appointments purpose.I was told I was also going to be starting autism testing in December 2021 with yet another new person. I started the autism testing with in person sessions again telling the same things about my mental health I had told lots of other professionals. Why couldn't they just share notes? I then got handed lots of questionnaires to complete. I then had a couple of other in person appointments then was told I would have another new person to do the diagnosis which really frustrated me. I met the new person early 2022 at a different location from my usual appointments which I didn't like. It still had the CAMHS usual young children orientated stuff which was patronising and I think a lot of older children and teens would think too. There should be a mix of decoration and things for younger and older patients in the CAMHS areas. They then got a psychiatrist in to see me to review getting medication. I got to meet the psychiatrist prior to the official review in a session with both of them which was nice.I went in for lots of appointments that felt a bit unnecessary with the new autism test staff. I had some other sessions with them and the psychiatrist to both confirm the autism and review medication for the depression which all felt like the multiple CAMHS appointments I'd been going to for years, telling the same stories about my mental health.In mid 2022 again and hit another crisis point. We sped up the medication review process and I finally got cleared for anti depressants August 2022 and started them. The anti depressents so far have helped. I then got officially diagnosed with autism September 2022 which helped answer a lot of questions and explained a lot of things about myself that I was unaware was autism. It was the things that ran deeper than the previously diagnosed anxiety an depression. I had felt like a broken human my whole life and now I realise I'm just wired differently.Unfortunately a late autism diagnosis is very common in women even though it would have helped me so much when I was younger and not think I'm just bad at being a person. It is important that we see the differences in autism within different genders at different ages and recognise and embrace them instead of dismissal.It's bittersweet I was one of the lucky people that got seen as I know the waiting list of thousands of people is overflowing and it's frustrating. Young people's mental health is at a crisis point and nobody seems to care until they're suicidal or dead with not enoulgh being done to prevent it. They're always being told it'll get better eventually, or that it's just hormones, which is mostly not the case and harmful to be told especially when there could be mental illness hiding in the darkness. CAMHS need to find a better system that works. Perhaps like having initial phone appointments with patients and streamlining them into areas such as anxiety help, autism diagnosis, depression help etc. Then being given out packs by post or email with resources to help cope with the areas of struggle (established during the initial call) between the first and future appointments. Also resources for parents to help understand and support their children in these packs. This would help tremendously even with the situation now until something else is sorted and added to this to get people seen and supported.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Dancer21
title: So wonderfully supportive
body:
I would like to highlight the utterly fabulous service of the Fife Breastfeeding Support Team and commend Kelly in particular for her care and support.  
To have a Breastfeeding Support Team available is a necessity for new mums (and I’m sure second/third and more time mums!) who benefit hugely from the skills and expertise of the team.  
As a new mum I felt supported by the team on numerous occasions where Kelly helped to support me through mastitis, nipple shields, position and latch, and much more.  
I am in complete support of the Breastfeeding Team and the inspiring role they play in a mother's breastfeeding journey. In support of the team, I wish to say that this is a key area of need and if we wish as a society to encourage new mothers to breastfeed. In my view, this service needs to be supported further financially and more staff added to the exceptional team in place just now.  
Breastfeeding is magical and such an important part of being a mother. However, we live in a society where often as a breastfeeding mother, you are in the minority. This means support is even more important and I cannot thank the Breastfeeding Team enough for helping me with my breastfeeding journey.  
My baby is now 10 months old and is exclusively breastfed despite several initial challenges I faced. I am very proud of this and I cannot thank the team enough for being so wonderfully supportive.

author: Markz95
title: Lack of access to NHS24
body:
I called NHS 24 about my daughters worsening back pain, however after 90 minutes I was getting nowhere & she was crying in pain. I reluctantly called 999 where I was told someone would call me back. An advanced practitioner called me back and after asking lots of questions said my call did not merit an ambulance and told me to call NHS 24 again. The practitioner was embarrassed and very apologetic & even said they were supposed to have a professional line they could call to save me queuing again but this line just rings out constantly which often results in ambulances being sent out unnecessarily.  
I was able to see that perhaps calling 999 was too much but I was desperate for help or even just advice but it seems impossible.  
I don't understand why 999 and NHS 24 can't link in with each other. How many ambulances are being wasted because 999 can't feed into NHS 24? I find it shocking!  
In the end I took my daughter to A & E because I was at my wits end when I just needed a doctor to see her and manage her pain.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: pelicangm87
title: Daughters care while in hospital
body: After waiting in the ambulance (paramedics were excellent| ) my daughter was admitted direct to a ward and from the moment she was admitted staff could not have been more helpful, attentive, informative or kind

readBy.name: South Western Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust

author: JaB22
title: Feeling very let down
body:
Feeling very let down. I was admitted to A&E, and they were brilliant. Moved to SAU, and the day staff were very good, the night staff not so good but acceptable.  
The problem started when I was transferred to Surgical Assessment Ward. The day staff were very good, but after being in the ward overnight with the air con going 24/7, I was stressed and crying. One of the nurses calmed me down, as I was ready to discharge myself. That was the first time anything was explained to me by the nurse, and then the night staff came on and were not interested. Patients were buzzing in, but they would come and put the buzzer off but not come back.  
I couldn't sleep and asked for a hot drink. It never came, so I went for a walk to find one. When I did, I sat and drank it at the vending machine and fell asleep. 3 hours later I went back to the ward, passed the nurses station, and never got a look. I was feeling better and my wife and daughter convinced me to stay, but it was very stressful and hope the next time will be better.

author: Spike1
title: Very well looked after all round
body: Had a procedure as soon as I arrived at hospital and then the after care was excellent. Very well looked after all round

author: Raquel46
title: I believe I owe my life to this service
body:
I came back to Inclusion in March. I was broken and had recently come out of hospital for the last time hopefully. I was very ill. I attended group sessions with Jason and Simon. All I can say is they saved my life.  
Jason deserves a medal! I never thought recovery would be like this (GOOD!) It is such a professional but friendly service, really diverse. The key workers are all great also. I enjoyed group, meditation, acupuncture at one time.  
Anyone struggling, I would highly suggest Inclusion. Personally, I believe I owe my life to this service. I have such fondness for Inclusion, I'm sad to be discharged!! I'll miss them,they are great!!!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Rumi
title: Urgent referal to neck lumo clinic - 18 weeks wait
body:
After being referrerd to the neck lump clinic via the urgent referral pathway, I received a letter with an appointment 13 weeks later. The appointment will be 18 weeks after initial referral! 18 weeks is a normal referral not an urgent one.  
I have contacted the patient experience team who were very pleasant and understanding and have lodged my complaint. However, this may take over 20 working days. Although this is being taken forward, my health has taken further deterioration and I am extremely frustrated at this point. Thus, I feel a need to share this publicly to raise awareness to the public and wider NHS services.  
I undestand the strains that are on the NHS right now however, this is incomprehensible. According to the Scottish government guidance on urgent referrals (2021) patients should not have to wait for 18 weeks.  
I am aware that I only moved 1 position on the waiting list in 11 days. That seems quite absurd for an urgent referral.  
I am struggling to function most days due to extreme exhaustion and have lost more weight since I was referred. My GP practice informed me that it is out of their hands once they have made the referral.  
I have had no information from any health professional about the delay. Is this not an inhumane way of treating people?  
My swollen lymph nodes may be attributed to stress, according to what I have read. I do hope this is the case however, this unexplained delay certainly doesn't help to reduce my stress levels.  
According to my socioeconomic and demographic background the Scottish government highlights the increased likelihood of health issues and a need for NHS to take this into consideration. I certainly don't feel my needs, (whether my swollen lymph nodes are related to stress or disease) are being considered in any way whatsoever.  
I notice a lot of responses for Lothian seems to be written by the patient experience team. I would be grateful to know if this story also goes to the department it's related to.

author: MrsA
title: The care and support we received was absolutely amazing
body:
We had a visit to PCMU a few weeks before the arrival of our little one, and felt really happy with the tour and information we were given - we knew it was the right place for us to meet our baby.  
When I went into labour, we called the unit and they put my mind at rest, explaining what was to come. Things moved quickly, and we ended up heading to the unit earlier than expected. We were met by a midwife and student midwife who checked me over, prepared the birthing pool and explained things to my husband and me. The care and support we received was absolutely amazing, and I feel so lucky to have been able to give birth with amazing women helping me.  
We were given special time with our newborn, and never felt rushed - the staff were very sensitive and considerate. When I was moved to the post natal room, we were looked after for the two nights my baby and I spent there, and everyone we met made it feel like such a homely place.  
We were very well looked after and I would highly recommend anyone to come here to have their babies. It feels a lot less medical than the hospital, and the one-to-one care makes the whole experience so much easier.

author: 1950dg
title: Kind, caring and thoughtful staff
body: I had a very satisfactory experience.  I was taken on time, both nurses who dealt with me were very professional. The nurse who gave me the information about the procedure put me at ease and took time to explain all aspects of what to expect. She was kind, caring and thoughtful and helped me to feel reassured and I ended my appointment feeling very happy with my experience.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: apuswb83
title: Getting tested with an sdi
body: Staff made me feel at ease as I felt embarrassed and ashamed of the situation.

author: flutewn48eden
title: Dedication of the ward housekeeper
body: I have heard a lot of negativity about Eden ward at moment and the one person keeps getting missed out is the dedication of the ward housekeeper. Every time he is on duty, he is non-stop working to keep the ward clean and tidy and helps us patients to keep our rooms tidy. He goes above and beyond and we think he deserves a gold star thank you Ian for what you do!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Kellycos
title: Fantastic service at the vaccine centre
body: My 2 y/o son attended for his flu vaccine today and we had a very positive experience. The clinic ran incredibly smoothly and efficiently and the staff were all warm and friendly. A HCSW, Frances, was particularly lovely and went out her way to engage with my son and create a fun environment…so much so, he walked out and said “that good fun”. A thank you and well done to all the staff.

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Lynsw34
title: Providing excellent care for the patient
body:
One of our patients was recently transferred to A&E and required to be accompanied by 4 staff. We were all made to feel welcome, the patient received a very prompt assessment and clear investigation and treatment plan.  
All staff were approachable and caring this included a consultant, HCSW, staff nurses and porter.  
The staff nurses in the short stay ward were especially helpful, keen to support and enquire re the wellbeing of those accompanying the patient.  
Thank you to all staff who helped to make this potentially difficult situation easier and providing excellent care for the patient.

author: That guy over there
title: It's what I needed
body: It is just what I needed. Thank you. Seriously, thank you.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: SaJF22
title: My baby being sick
body: Our 6 month old baby was taken to resus in A&e Altnagelvin last week and we couldn't be more greatful to nurses Shannon, Aideen & Geraldine & Dr Jonathan who looked after him. Kept us calm and worked so well and fast with him when he was unwell. Very reassuring to know we were in the best hands.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: ulsterphysio
title: Second failed telephone review
body:
This is my second telephone review appointment which didn't happen. I have a cardiac history and am normally reviewed every 2 years, but haven't had any contact since 2019. I received a letter reminder for a telephone review which told me to allow 60 mins each side of appointment time, which didn't happen.  
I didn't hear anything since to tell me why I wasn't called or reviewed. I then received a letter in August this year to be seen. I work on acute care in a hospital setting, so had to allow 60 mins either side of appointment time, only to have no contact made again.  
I feel this an absolute disgrace. This could be handled better. The doctor may be busy, but it only takes a phone call from an administrator to re-book or apologise.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: JOHnx79
title: An operation on my hand
body:
I attended the above unit for an operation on my left hand. I feel compelled to write to thank the staff within this unit for the exceptional level of care I received during my stay.  
Everyone from the Reception staff to the Surgeon ( Mr Lohana ) could not have been more attentive or understanding in their duties.  
Particular mention should be given to Jodie and her staff in the recovery area who diligently ensured myself, and all my fellow patients, were looked after. They were beyond considerate in their care and nursing for all the patients.

author: Livedtotellthetale
title: My sister's life was saved
body: My sister’s life was saved at Crosshouse hospital after she suffered from a suspected AFE after the birth of her son. This happened a few years ago but I have only just found this page. The consultant on call recognised the condition and acted promptly. We had a very tense wait while she was in theatre and then afterwards in Intensive Care in an induced coma. At all times throughout, the staff were amazing. Forever grateful to NHS staff. 💚

author: AnotherMum
title: His care was excellent
body: My son had an endoscopy under general anaesthetic in early September. Everyone who looked after him was so nice and friendly and explained everything very well to him. His care was excellent.

author: Shades
title: I was quite anxious about the procedure
body: I underwent a TOE (transoesophageal echocardiogram) for investigation and assessment of an atrial septal defect (a hole in the heart) that was recently diagnosed. The required a scope like an endoscope to be passed into my gullet under sedation and local throat spray. I was quite anxious about this.The staff were brilliant and put me at ease, and the procedure went well. The consultant came to give me a full explanation of the results. I'm relieved that it went well.

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Male Medical is good, cannot say anything bad about it
body:
Accident and Emergency was busy but got seen to quite quickly, could not really complain about it.  
The staff are exceptional there I have to say.  
Male medical is good cannot say anything bad about it. The food is good and there is plenty on the plate, you could near get two meals out of it. The environment is fine I am coping fine with it, which I am glad of. The level of care is good, I can feel myself getting better.  
The staff are good and they go above and beyond for everyone if they can. They try and make everyone comfortable, and make it feel like a hotel with the care they give me.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The level of care is very good
body:
Accident and Emergency was a long wait, and waiting on a bed was longer. The care was good and they got me stabilised.  
The staff are excellent, they know everything and help as much as they possibly can.  
Male Medical is fine, I have not got up yet as I am on the oxygen tank, so hopefully get on my feet soon with the physio's help. The food is not great but I have to eat it. The level of care is very good, they make sure you get seen to all your needs.  
The staff are good, they try their best and make sure you are getting better. You are never stuck, there is always someone about to help and they drop everything for you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Annqr65
title: Every member of staff was so friendly, caring and considerate
body: I attended South Tyrone Hospital Day Surgery Unit for an endoscopy and wish to thank each and every member of staff for their care and attention during my visit. Every step of the procedure was explained and every member of staff was so friendly, caring and considerate. Thank you again.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: BumbleBee2323
title: I felt very seen, supported and listened to
body:
I have endometriosis, ibd and cuti and I wanted to get the coil for more reliable contraception, and also to help manage my endometriosis pain.  
I had a nurse who was very understanding and I felt very safe. She has set up a follow-up appointment with a doctor to try and help me with a less painful coil insertion due to my conditions. I really appreciated the nurse for looking out for my best interests and taking the time to listen, and to support me when the coil insertion wasn't possible.  
I've had a variety of experiences with medical professionals, and some have been overwhelmingly bad. This was not one of those times. I felt very seen, supported and listened to during my appointment. I felt a lot better attending a sexual health clinic vs GP for this procedure.  
I would definitely use this service again in the future. I've had a lot of experience with medical professionals in the last five years, and it has really taught me to be grateful to the people who treat you like a person and who do their best to support you.  
Thanks again

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Daisyhillnewry
title: This service is invaluable
body: My father had an appointment in Daisy Hill Hospital in the OPAU. I, one of dad’s daughters, accompanied him. We cannot commend the staff highly enough. Each & every member of staff who looked after dad was pleasant, courteous, friendly and professional. Dad had a full M.O.T., he was treated with care & dignity. This service is invaluable to the elderly in the community & their families.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Concerendfriend
title: Lack of aftercare and support
body:
Having recently seen this service in action whilst supporting a friend. It really disappoints the lack of care and support there is out there for these ladies. No mental health support available very little aftercare has been provided/ available.  
It’s a very traumatic experience for sone people no matter what stage the pregnancy. It’s sad this service is so lacking in this day and age.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: PeteE22
title: Operation on my hand
body: I had an Operation to remove a lump from the palm of my hand. It was done at Cannock Hospital as a day case. The whole experience, from beginning to end, was excellent. The day was very organised, everything was explained well, the staff were very caring a helpful and the hospital itself was very clean and tidy. If I ever had to have surgery again I would be very happy to go back to Cannock. Thank you.

author: Anxiousmum
title: Keep up the fantastic work you do
body:
My dad was admitted through SATA at The Queen Elizabeth University Hospital Glasgow one week ago with what turned out to be pneumonia. From his initial assessment in SATA he was then admitted to ARU 5 for 24hrs before finally being admitted to Ward 7B, where he is still a patient.  
The care he has received in all has been exceptional, all of these units were extremely busy but they still found time to keep my mum updated . SATA provided him with the essential cups of tea and biscuits he needed to keep him going, and were so thorough in their investigations they can’t be faulted.  
ARU 5 updated my mum in in the morning when she called regarding how he was overnight, and 7B again have been fantastic putting him at his ease as he’s never been in hospital before in his 80 yrs, and if possible they let my mum speak to him on the phone most mornings.  
On top of all this, the medical care he’s received has been second to none, what a great job you all do. Hopefully he will be home soon, but all these little touches make such a difference, especially to the patient but also to the families that are worrying at home .  
Keep up the fantastic work you do.

author: plutocz95
title: The staff were amazing and so helpful
body: My daughters were in an RTC and brought to DHH Emergency Department. The staff there were amazing and so helpful, Rebecca from the Children’s ward came down to help with covid swabs and was very patient and understanding with my daughter who needed it. The radiographers were so good when my eldest needed to get x-rayed, they were very patient and gentle. I’m so grateful to the nurses and doctors that looked after both my girls in DHH ED. One of my girls had to be kept over night and due to her age was transferred to Blossom Ward at Craigavon. The staff there were so helpful, Lauren the band 6 took such good care of my daughter and I’m so grateful for the time that was taken to put us both at ease at what was a stressful time.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Hamish52
title: In & out with no problems
body: Very quick professional informative and friendly appointment.  Made sure i was comfortable with everything.  In and out no problem.

author: Pineg65
title: Excellent services
body:
NHS BORDERS WELL BEING  
Excellent, timely, kind and empathetic services  
[Happy with 'Appointments']  
  
[Unsure about 'Transport']  
  
[Very happy with 'Reception']  
[Unsure about 'Environment']

author: ScoobyDoo1
title: Walked away with a smile on my face
body:
Had the best appointment ever in the past 4 years after attending the hospital for a couple of years, much longer with my doctor, to feel like someone was actually listening for a change, wasn’t rushed, asked plenty of questions and how myself was feeling. First time with a new clinic, a rheumatology nurse, and physiotherapist together, Susan and Paula (Kirkcaldy Fife).  
My head wasn’t thinking straight and missed a few things, I realised once I'd left, but I’m sure the next appointment will be better, as my dad was in hospital day before with a heart attack…  
But can honestly say it’s the first time I’ve walked away with a smile on my face and feel like I’m getting somewhere. Got both of my hands scanned on the day and felt so at ease. I’ve told everybody it’s the first time I can honestly say that someone was listening to me in years.

author: star22
title: I attended for peace of mind
body: i first made a phone call and expressed i hadnt any symptoms but wanted an sti test for peace of mind and i was given an appointment at stafford. i arrived at the clinic, the receptionist was friendly and helpful, i then went through with the nurse who asked me some questions and asked if i had any questions, she then explained what i needed to do clearly, i found the nurse to be reassuring, patient, friendly, and gentle when taking my bloods. the clinic was also very clean and tidy

author: User3584
title: Treatment for genital warts
body:
I have had two appointments at Tamworth, two weeks apart. Both times the staff were friendly, and respectful, and performed the freezing treatment effectively.

The woman on the desk was also friendly and polite.

The service was quick and efficient, and the reminder texts were discreet, and helpful.

The late opening was very useful too, as it enabled me to attend the clinic outside of office hours, so I didn't have to take any time off work.

author: Sarabeen
title: The procedure went very well
body:
I attended the Endoscopy unit at the above hospital. Everyone on the team were kind , respectful, gentle and with their reassurance I felt relaxed and the procedure went very well.  
5 stars to them all and their wonderful sense of humour . Thank you x

author: MixerB
title: Care provided within the Beatson
body:
In March, my nephew was diagnosed with a metastatic germ cell tumour after attending A&E for a non-related incident.  
He was, and remains, under the care of Dr White at the Beatson, and I can honestly say his care has been fantastic. During his inpatient stay within Ward B7 he was treated with absolute dignity and respect and as a family we were included in every decision, taking time to explain his treatment plan often on more than one occasion if we hadn’t processed all the information.  
Whilst undergoing chemo he also had to manage his Type 1 diabetes alongside his Asperger’s, and as a family we were supported in our suggestion to have someone stay with him overnight to ensure his BMs were checked regularly and acted upon accordingly; although I have no doubt the nursing staff would happily have done this. The staff recognised his individual needs and without a doubt his care was patient-centred and tailored to his needs.  
The emotional support we received from Julie was fantastic. She always gave as much time as was needed to allow us to talk and ask questions. She was honest regarding the treatment and the impact this would be likely to have on him both physically and emotionally, however ensured the support was there when needed.  
As it stands he has completed his chemo, undergone surgery and beginning to look at his maintenance care, but most importantly he’s looking forward to enjoying life to its fullest.  
Thank you to Dr White, Julie, and all the nursing, domestic and healthcare assistants, alongside anyone else involved in his care. Xx

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Accident and emergency is a mess
body:
Accident and emergency is a mess, the waiting times were not acceptable, and especially not on those chairs you are made to sit on. The results take far too long to come, what if there is something majorly wrong with me and they do not get the results for multiple hours.  
The staff were fine they just wanted you out of their way since they had a lot to do. The things wrong with here is nothing to do with the staff it is the amount of staff to people ratio.  
Female medical has been very good, the attention you get is amazing anything you ask for you get. The treatment you receive is very good, I just need to get out of here.  
The staff are fantastic, they are outstanding any positive word you can think of they are. You only get the best from them and they are totally honest with you about your care and if you are getting any better.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: apuspe98
title: Thank you one and all
body:
I was submitted to CCU after suffering a cardiac arrest. As you would expect, I was placed in an induced coma once I arrived at Ninewells Hospital, Dundee. Once I woke up and became more aware, I was extremely pleased with the time staff took to speak to me in order to help me understand what happened to me. I guess more importantly explain the steps I would face going forward.  
I found Kevin from CCU Ward 20 particularly attentive. Kevin took time to visit me when I had been moved to Ward 1. Overall, I found all staff polite and helpful. The staff did not always get things right first time (minor issues), however it was heartening that they made sure to involve me in decision making throughout my time in their care. Everyone from porters, nurses, doctors and consultants were attentive, though Kevin displayed exceptional willingness to make sure the service received was great.  
Importantly, I was not rushed or hassled at any point in my stay, which helped me both mentally, physically and emotionally.  
Thank you one and all, with a special thank you to Kevin😁

author: sigmabq58
title: My short hospital visit
body:
I was collected by ambulance from home to Treliske hospital and I spent the next 12/13 hours in the back of 2 different ambulances (after a shift change). I would like to thank Darren and Sanch (not sure I spelt that correctly) from the first ambulance and Bradley and Claire from the second ambulance for their kindness to me. Such caring people they made me relax and enjoy a good laugh while waiting on me hand and foot. I felt like I was in my own private hospital ward with 2 nurses of my own. When you are a bit anxious and worried about the outcome of your hospital visit, it’s lovely that people can make you feel like they’ve known you for much longer. All the staff I met were smiling and gentle. There was Ben from (RATS) Rapid Access and Treatment Service, who sang his way softly through all my procedures, knowing all the words to the songs playing quietly in the background. The first lovely voice I heard. I must mention the nurses in the Discharge lounge who, when I was left on my own to wait to be picked up, gave me a couple of Beatle songs. Lovely voices too! My thanks go to all the staff for their hard work and dedication in these difficult times.  
Yours gratefully,

readBy.name: South Western Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The environment is good
body:
Accident and emergency was dead on, just so long to wait on everything. I got triaged quickly but after that it was a long process to getting admitted.  
The staff were okay, they were stressed out and had a lot to do.  
Female medical has been good cannot complain about it, the environment is good it is nice and warm and the ward is busy all the time. The food is good especially the potato and leek soup.  
The staff are as pleasant as can be, they know literally everything you can ask them anything. They keep me informed with my care and the level of care I am receiving is very good. Hopefully I am fit to go home soon.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: FVRH22
title: Disappointed with poor A&E care
body:
Attended before 22:00 on a Saturday, after being directed from 111, due to rectal bleeding. Triaged just after midnight where I was taken through to department, given oral painkillers and left on a chair. That chair would be where I sat for 7+Hours before a doctor would see me. During which time, despite active bleeding my blood pressure was not taken, I feel like staff went out there way to not look at me. I was sitting next to 2 elderly inpatients, 1 of which asked for pain relief 3 times, ended up getting paracetamol from another patient. They were in the department 12+ hours however some intoxicated patients given beds.  
I was reviewed by doctor in treatment room, and was told I could rest on the trolley. I asked for painkillers and blanket and had to go look for this 1 hour later. Then put back in Chair for 2-3 hours.  
I was then told I was going to get a bed up in ward B12 SAU, on arrival to that ward, myself and 3 other A&E patients were left in corridor of ward on chair, one patient being sick in floor, as the ward was full with no beds.  
The emergency department made me feel worthless, like I was just another hindrance, I’ve never been so upset with the treatment not only me, but others received.  
In B12 there was lovely staff who despite not having beds, reassured us, empathised and done what they could and were so attentive despite high demands.  
I basically felt like I was in a cattle market in A&E and, as a nurse myself with years of A&E experience, I was embarrassed and ashamed. The fact I was admitted with active bleeding but to have 7 hours pass whilst in the department and not so much as have my blood pressure recorded was nothing short of negligence.

readBy.name: Office of Murdo Fraser, MSP for Mid Scotland & Fife

author: Stone Free Patient
title: World class service in urology
body:
The professionalism and expert care given by Mr. Kata was outstanding. We are so grateful to him for his time and we feel so fortunate to have had his excellent consultation. He reassured us and the whole experience could not have been improved.  
I am impressed with his timeliness and no rush attitude. He takes the time to answer your questions and to identify options for issues. He made me feel relaxed and explained my kidney stones diagnosis and need for surgery thoroughly.  
The entire day case surgery experience was lovely, the staff were very friendly, kind and helpful. The ODP, anesthetic and nurses were so cheerful and happy which was wonderful. Well done NHS Fife team!

author: nitratesq44
title: Recovery support
body: On behalf of myself i would like to thank nicky the nurse and becci my recovery worker for all the help and support i receive, and ongoing support they are giving me at the gosport hub.

author: lesleyf
title: Coming to terms with bladder cancer
body:
Great support given by Sharon who signposted route for support during the pandemic.  
I was diagnosed with non invasive bladder cancer in March 2021.  
It came as a great shock as I hadn’t experienced any symptoms.  
It was a very difficult time to seek for help, as we were in the middle of the Covid pandemic.  
The support I received helped me to come to terms with facing up to treatment and on going tests.  
Thanks to people like Sharon, cancer patients are enabled to move forward on their journey.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: empathyhx55
title: Sorting a long term problem
body:
Old genital warts & ill health hampered me getting round to sorting the problem. I got in touch with clinic, fast response by today's situations.  
Put at ease with prompt, friendly treatment by all staff.

author: tommyj02
title: These NHS workers are doing a great job
body:
The team at the Orthopedic Pre-Assessment Unit is amazing. I had to go twice as my original appointment showed that my blood pressure was high. During both visits the staff could not have been more friendly and also informative throughout.  
On my return appointment my blood pressure was still high at the clinic, even though my daily readings had dropped down into the normal range after taking BP medication. Karen at the clinic was very understanding regarding my nervousness around my blood pressure reading and allayed my fears of a further delay in getting my total knee replacement.  
I promised Karen and her team a box of sweeties as a thanks for their kindness. When it is OK to bring in treats post-covid, I will arrange for the delivery. These NHS workers are doing a great job in my eyes.

author: Josef22
title: Changed my life and perspective
body:
I arrived at the Dame Carol Detox Unit due to an alcohol addiction which had developed and snowballed during the Covid Lockdowns.  
I was sceptical, anxious and truthfully rather frightened on arrival.The staff addressed my concerns within moments of me walking though the door, and helped me settle in seamlessly with my fellow residents.  
They didnt judge me, they taught me new ways of solving my problems and the Medical staff safely removed my dependence on alcohol.  
After two weeks, I feel like a new person, and for the first time in a long time am looking forward to the future.  
They gave me my heath and confidence back, and I finally feel like the best version of me again.  
I cannot thank the staff enough for what they did for me, and would recommend this wonderful team to anyone who are suffering like I did.

author: Einstein
title: Lack of response to patient needs
body: I have received a number of confusing letters concerning my heart condition. As the Cardiology Dept and main switchboard do not answer the telephone, I cannot clarify the situation. Also the automatic answering system is defective.

author: Skoda
title: Very happy with staff and care
body:
[Very happy with 'Appointments']  
I was very happy with the staff and care from the Vanguard Endoscopy Unit. I was taken on time and put at ease.

author: debbiec
title: Caring and reassuring nurse colposcopist
body:
I attended a colposcopy appointment in early August 2022 and met with Heather (Advance Nurse Specialist/Nurse Colposcopist) and would like to inform you of the wonderful way in which she conducted my appointment with her.  
She showed such empathy and put me completely at ease as I had been waiting a number of weeks for this appointment and was upset as well as very nervous and very apprehensive. She was so caring and reassuring. A credit to the NHS.  
If possible could you please pass on my sincere thanks and gratitude to her.

author: Dissappointed70
title: Medical care at Musgrave Park
body:
My mother, who has severe dementia, fell and broke her hip. She was initially seen at Antrim Area Hospital, who then transferred her to The Royal Victoria Hospital (RVH) for surgery. Care at the RVH was fine. My Father who is now extremely hard of hearing had been accompanied by either my sister, or myself so that we could help him understand anything that was said or answer any medical questions posed by staff. This was acceptable at both Antrim and RVH.  
Upon transfer to Musgrave Park Hospital this changed. Senior staff refused to allow this to happen, despite us explaining the situation. As I had arrived with my father on the first visit we were told that on this occasion only both could see her, but it would be for a reduced time 30mins, instead of 60mins.  
On entering the ward I allowed my father to go to my mothers bed, while I spoke to a nurse to check on her care and make sure they had all relevant information.  
So this is were it all starts to go down hill.  
Firstly, the RVH hadn’t informed them of my mother being lactose intolerant. If given dairy products she will get severe migraine and diarrhoea. The nurse apologised saying she had already given her some ice cream as she hadn’t been eating or drinking for at least 72hrs prior to being transferred. She added the lactose intolerance information to the medical notes for future reference.  
So now the fun begins. My father has to pre-book 1 hour visits, but now only he can visit. Every day either myself or my sister would make 1 phone call to check in with ward as my father can’t hear and therefore can’t tell us much.  
On three occasions this week, after being informed of her lactose intolerance, they have said they fed her ice-cream. This has resulted in diarrhoea, which with her not drinking properly is not helping her fluid levels. They have a sign over her bed about lactose intolerance and still they give her dairy products.  
All in all, what with her dementia, extreme confusion, recent surgery etc. this is a totally unacceptable level of care from so called health professionals.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: RobTom
title: Interventional Radiology at Victoria Hospital Kirkaldy
body: I had a Hickman line put in by the team at Victoria Hospital today. They were magnificent: friendly, professional and caring. They did their utmost to make what could be a scary procedure as comfortable and reassuring as possible. Thank you also to the people on Ward 34 who cared for me before and after the procedure - who were equally good!

author: Heaye79
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Satisfied with the service
body: I feel very satisfied with the service I receive from the Heart Failure team.

author: COM43
title: The staff here are excellent
body: The lady who gave me some vaccines due and a blood test provided an exceptional level of care, and put me at my ease. I hardly felt anything when the vaccines were given and blood test administered. The level of service was excellent and the facilities were immaculately clean. Thank you so much for being kind. I think all the staff here are excellent, highly professional and would really recommend you use these facilities if they are required.

author: ferrisc02
title: Thanks so much again for all your help!
body: I had to attend Endoscopy in Altnagelvin today for an OGD test. All the nurses that looked after me were exceptional, so helpful and honestly couldn’t do enough for me. A special thank you to Alex for doing my procedure, she was a real lady and took time to explain everything to me prior to and after my procedure. Thanks so much again for all your help!

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Kat Jones
title: A days work to them, meant the world to us
body:
Our 3 month old son recently developed an infection which went into his blood. We came to the Children's hospital through A&E where the nurses and doctors took a vigilant approach to his symptoms. At the time it could have been dismissed as a viral infection however the view was cautious and we were subsequently moved to 2c.  
We were there for a number of days where the diagnosis came within 12 hours of testing. He was difficult to cannulate and keep cannulated however his wellbeing was their upmost concern. The teams did everything possible to keep him comfortable and following several failed cannulas, they took him to theatre late on the Friday night to put in a long line. Naturally, I was hyper cautious about his temperature and any small sign he might be deteriorating but the teams were really kind and patient.  
They worked hard to keep us as parents reassured, and comfortable as well. We were then moved to 3c ortho for further care and again, the teams couldn't do enough for our son, or us. His long line failed after 2 days but the teams suggested a process that would keep his next canula viable and it did. We were apprehensive about brining him home ahead of the initial 14 days that had been suggested. The teams were understanding and offered us extra days and took time to explain the process to us and that he was well enough to come home. We never felt any pressure that they needed the bed, quite the opposite. We really can't thank the teams enough for their diligence, professionalism, kindness and patience during one of the most stressful times of our lives. We are so blessed to have the NHS and the people who dedicate their lives to the service. A days work for them, meant the world to us and now we have our health baby boy home.  
In terms of the other services you don't necessarily think of, the room we were in was kept really clean, we were fed every day and we went to the medi-cinema which was great for our older son to come and see his brother in a less scary environment. The park outside is great for some air, we were able to take him out in his pram a number of times. The is a night cafe which was weirdly nice to be able to do when I couldn't sleep - it was just somewhere to go. The shower was also surprisingly good.  
[Very happy with 'Treatment']  
  
[Very happy with 'Involved in decisions']

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Bernie58
title: Felt comfortable and well looked after for skin biopsy
body:
I was treated and looked after by Miss Tyers, Fiona and Clare. A skin biopsy was taken. The whole procedure was explained to me and the process afterwards and what to expect.  
I felt extremely well looked after, I was made to feel comfortable and at ease. The after care and information going forward was very useful and a leaflet (a reminder and explanation if you have questions after).  
Thank you Miss Tyers, Fiona and Clare your kindness and care was very much appreciated.

author: Rubberlegs
title: Lumbar puncture by a respectful and caring doctor
body:
I had a lumbar puncture recently in ward 53 at QEUH. Can I just say the staff were amazing.  
The doctor who carried out the LP was so respectful, caring and really listened to my fears and concerns. I cried the whole way through and had some minimal pain and discomfort but definitely felt listened to and cared for. Cups of tea and a sandwich also definitely made the day brighter.  
I cannot thank them enough and although in pain today, glad its all over and hopefully get some answers soon. Honestly the best admission I've had over the past few years and definitely take pride in their care and attention.  
Nothing was too much trouble for them. Absolutely outstanding. Thank you to all staff members.

author: Jayne79
title: Carpel tunnel surgery
body:
I attended Duke of Connaught Day Procedure Unit Musgrave Park hospital. This was my second hand having surgery for carpel tunnel. What a smooth system is in place. All the staff were so professional and caring. The "hi" from professionals going past in their scrubs in the waiting area, helped settle my nerves. The unit is so clean. Mr Swain's team put me at ease and ensured I had a review before the procedure took place.  
Working in healthcare myself, the nurse that sat with me is a credit to the nursing profession, put me at ease and so caring, sometimes we loose sight of how this basic nursing care means so much to the patient. Having attended Wither's four years ago for my first hand, I found this experience less nerve wrecking. Taken on time and on way home within, hour and half. Thanks to everyone for their care.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
